I've done a fair bit of resin casting. People seeing my castings with insects get excited and almost always want to get one their self. -Do one for me! -Nope, it's to much work to just give away. -But it's just a piece of plastic!? -Yep, now it is, but first you need to catch the bug, kill it without damaging it, mount it nice and let it dry for several weeks, then cast in at least three, often four or five layers, not letting dust in and then sand and polish each piece for several hours. Your not getting sh*t from me!

Can you make a video tackling how one could remove various papers and glues from plastic and glass containers? The first thing that came to my mind for removing the molds was to dissolve the molds off, and maybe even the surface layer of the plastic with a wash of [something]. I suppose glass would be easy, using acetone or some other acid - but on plastic, stuff like that instantly ruins and dissolves/discolors the plastic. Is there a chemical way to clean plastic? This could be very useful for people that like to remove glue/paper from plastic things, but want to preserve the plastic thing itself. Finding a way to remove/dissolve just the very top layer would be the key part of this. This method could even be used to refinish and smooth out a damaged plastic surface.

So even with foamcore the biggest mistake I saw was that you tried making the molds as they lay on their side.
If you'd made a mold for something like that, next time make it as a vertical mold.
1) thin metal line hot-glue tack'd to the ampule (so it can hang in the mold as it is filled. It also allows for an integrated 'loop' for the ornament or necklace)
2) attach metal line to a thin dowel (or in your case propbably a long wooden pencil-->pour 1/3 of the resin in and wait until gel phase-->pour next 1/3 to ensure ampules hang centered-->pour last third in.

:)

You really do make fantastic content for the curious and nerdy amoung us, but I have to say that as a trained lamp worker the glassblower inside of me cringes every time I see you make ampules! It's a similar process to what's called "pulling points" off tubing to use as handles for making larger vessels, but in that application we like to make sure everything's as straight as possible... I really don't think that matters for your purposes, though! :) Seriously much love, brother.

As a fan of both science and arts and crafts, I loved this video. For future reference, if you ever want to make a silicone mold and don't have proper molding silicone on hand, you can make something kind of close enough out of silicone caulk and corn starch or glycerine. (Possibly also DOT-3 or DOT-4 brake fluid; I haven't tried that myself, but if you read on, you'll see why that might work.) Make sure the caulk is labeled as 100% silicone; you should be able to get plenty at your local hardware store.) When you mix up molding silicone, there are two main components: 1) a mixture that reacts with moisture from the air to form silicone rubber and 2) a hygroscopic component to help pull moisture from the air. Silicone caulk is basically the first part without the second, because it's meant to be applied in such thin layers that it cures in minutes just on its own.

How exactly you proceed depends on how fast you want the mold to set and how long it takes to get the mold formed. I would highly recommend you not imitate me the first time I did this and mix one part corn starch to three parts silicone to make a mold of highly-detailed laurel leaves. (It was for the crown on a friend's costume.) I barely managed to get the mold around the initial clay sculpture before it set too much to manipulate. Smaller amounts of the hygroscopic component will give you a longer curing time. Additionally, glycerine will give you a better working texture, because it does not have the physical baggage of being a basically dry, bulky powder. I've also seen molding silicone made by squirting an entire tube of silicone caulk into a bowl of dilute dish soap in water, kneading it a little, then pulling the whole mass out to mold around an object, but I've never tried this myself.

I work as a mechanic these days, so I'm familiar with the fact that DOT-3 or -4 brake fluid is an extremely hygroscopic fluid, which might be good for texture and probably cheaper than glycerine, but I don't know how it would react chemically with silicone rubber. Since it's glycol-based, I think you'd be okay, but I've never tried it. I'm also not entirely certain it would be called DOT-3 or DOT-4 in Canada, since the DOT refers to the US Department of Transportation, but I don't know what else to call it. Basically, a glycol-based brake fluid that boils between 205-230°C when dry.
